10/ The invasion of Afghanistan was just. But the right path would have been a quicker exit rather than a 20 year occupation. 

The continued magical thinking that we could have won Afghanistan if we stayed longer is bound to get us into trouble later. 

Hubris breeds hubris.

9/ Finally, there was no world in which Biden could have just "stuck it out". That would have required tens of thousands more troops and a resumption of deadly fighting with the Taliban.

And the design flaws of the first 20 years wouldn't have vanished if we stayed longer.

8/ For centuries, the Afghans have resisted conquest and control. The power and strength of the instinct to fight America and the West was always going to be stronger than the willingness to work with us.

Resistance is in the soul of Afghanistan.

7/ More importantly, there was likely NEVER going to be a plan - even if it was informed by a better cultural understanding - that could impose a foreign power's will on Afghanistan. Sometimes, there is no American plan that will work.
6/ But if you don't know how to properly spend money, who to partner with, how to build sustainable governments, etc, than there's no amount of money that will fix a fundamentally flawed strategy.

5/ The "can do" spirit of our military is its greatest strength and liability. In Afghanistan, the military's failed to understand that a paper thin understanding of Afghan culture and society was destined to lead to planning failure. But, admirably, they couldn't accept failure.

4/ Every time I visited Afghanistan, a new smart general would explain to me why the previous general screwed up and how his new plan (derived from maybe 30 days of on-the-ground learning) would get things on the right track.

3/ From the start, we didn't understand Afghanistan, a country wildly different from and more complicated than Iraq.

And our structure of rotating generals and soldiers in and out 12 months at a time meant that we were destined to never learn Afghanistan.

2/ Patraeus says the problem was a) we refused to stay longer; b) we spent too little $ and on the wrong stuff; and c) we didn't understand Afghanistan.

What he fails to realize is that (a) and (b) don't matter if (c) is true.

I greatly respect General Patraeus, but there is real danger is allowing the magical thinking of "if we had spent more money or stayed longer everything would have been fine" to persist.

1/ A few thoughts on why "more" wouldn't have fixed Afghanistan.

Oil operates similarly to other commodities: the more regulations, the more uncertainties in demand, and the more constraints on capital all lead to a great deal of volatility in the market. 

More simply: the market needs certainty to operate well. And we don‚Äôt have it.

And why are prices so different ($2.27 in July 2020 vs $4.67 July 2022) if demand is so similar?  Because Joe Biden‚Äôs policies and his party‚Äôs rhetoric have created wild instability and unpredictability in the oil and gas market.
So what‚Äôs going on here? It‚Äôs pretty obvious: High prices under Joe Biden have destroyed demand for gasoline, even *more* so than the lockdowns that kept Americans off the road.

According to the U.S.‚Äôs Energy Information Administration (EIA) it was a more sour outlook:

‚ÄúAmericans are officially driving less than they did in the summer of 2020, when pandemic travel restrictions all but halted movement.‚Äùhttps://www.bnnbloomberg.ca/summer-gasoline-demand-in-us-drops-below-pandemic-levels-1.1800928

Because it‚Äôs an established cycle, analysts can model it out to predict supply and predict demand and match the two.
